FacilityName: Alta-Dena Certified Dairy, LLC - Buena Park
SafetyInspectionBy: Orange County Health Care Agency - Environ. Health

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED:



Dean Foods of California, LLC of Buena Park, CA produces ice cream and frozen desserts.  The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as refrigerant to freeze ice cream and to maintain the proper temperature of ice cream and frozen desserts within the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is an effective and environmentally friendly refrigerant that has been used for many years by most food processing facilities.  The refrigerant would be a gas at ambient temperatures, but is handled as a gas liquefied under pressure in a closed loop refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system consists of a high-pressure receiver, recirculators, condensers, evaporators, compressors, piping, and valves.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



As a part of its PMS Program, Dean Foods utilizes all the Elements of the PSM/RMP/CalARP requirements which are helpful in maintaining our system in very good condition and preventing accidental releases of ammonia.  These Elements included:



     Process Safety Information

     Process Hazard Analysis

     Operation Procedures

     Training

     Mechanical Integrity

     Management of Changd

     Pre-Startup Review

     Compliance Audits

     Incident Investigations

     Employee Participation

     Hot Work Permits

     Contractor Safety



EMERGENCY RESPONSE INFORMATION:



As a part of the PSM Program, the facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan that was prepared in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency incident, and to increase the realibility of actions taken during an incident.  The plan includes all the requirements of an emergency action plan.



In the event of an emergency involving the refrigeration system, it is the policy of the facility to request assistance as necessary by calling 911, which will notify the California Region 1 LEPC.  In addition, the LEPC has included Dean Foods in its local emergency response p

lanning.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDSENT HISTORY:



The facility has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due in part to our stringent release prevention programs, there have been no accidental release during this period.



STEPS TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



Since the last RMP submission, our facility has removed insulation from the intercooler and low temperature recirculator vessels, inspected the bare metal on the vessels, applied RG 2400 Reactive Gel to the metal surfaces and re-insulated the vessels.  The reactive gel is known as Bluegoo and is to stop or prevent corrosion under insulation.  Employee training and operating procedure reviews are emphad as part of continuous improvement goals at our facility.  The facility will continue to operate and maintain the refrigeration system in accordance with industry association standards and will continue operate under the PSM/RMP/CalARP Program requirements.



EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSES:



Under CalARP program requirements, applicable external events are considered within the hazard review.  Hazard reviews are encompassed within a complete Process Safety Management program, which is reviewed and updated every five years.  Such events included, but were not limited to; seismic activity & sabotage with the effect on safety of the facility and the surroundings being considered.



SABOTAGE



The Dean Foods facility installed a surveillance system.  The facility has restricted access within the production facility.  A key code entry is required to gain access to the production facility and refrigeration room.  For these reasons, the likelihood of a chemical accident was considered remote.



SEISMIC ACTIVITY



The potential for earthquakes, and the possible effect on the facility were taken into account.  The existing seismic restraints incorporated into the facility/equipment design were also considered.  In the event of a loss of pressure in the refrigeration system due to a system bre

ach, the system would be automatically shut down via pressure sensing controls and/or ammonia sensors.



FIRE / EXPLOSION



An emergency ventilation system is in place which would operate automatically to maintain the concentration of ammonia in the Engine Room at no more than 25% of the  lower explosive level.  Obviously, the possibility of an explosion and/or fire related to the facility refrigeration system was considered, although the occurrence would be very remote.  In such an event, the refrigeration (ignition) source would be removed by shutting down the feed valves and appropriate safety measures would be taken by operation personnel.  If a fire is of an electrical nature, power to the affected area would be shut down via circuit breakers.



WEATHER



Various weather conditions, and their possible effect on the facilities refrigeration system were also studied, and considered to be remote.
